ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Did Tokyo billboard show "Stop War, Stop Zelensky"?

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... Kishida to Kyiv in March 2023, and attending the G7 summit in Hiroshima two months later.
Zelensky appealed directly to other leaders during his visit to Japan in May, comparing the destruction of Bakhmut in the east of Ukraine to the decimation of Hiroshima during World War II.
However, according to at least one tweet shared online this week, support toward the Ukrainian leader is not well-shared across the country, with a billboard in one of Japan's busiest districts seemingly carrying anti-Zelensky propaganda.
!
Volodymyr Zelensky during a joint press conference on July 11, 2023 in Kyiv, Ukraine and a photo of Shibuya, Tokyo, Japan. A video shared by a YouTuber appeared to show an anti-Zelensky billboard on show... Volodymyr Zelensky during a joint press conference on July 11, 2023 in Kyiv, Ukraine and a photo of Shibuya, Tokyo, Japan. A video shared by a YouTuber appeared to show an anti-Zelensky billboard on show in the busy Shibuya neighborhood. More Vitalii Nosach/Global Images Ukraine via Getty; Getty
The Claim
 by YouTuber Jackson Hinkle, posted on July 31, 2023, viewed 447,000 times, shows a video of what appears to be a billboard in Japan, stating "Stop War, Stop Zelenskyy."
! Newsletter
The Bulletin
Your Morning Starts Here
Begin your day with a curated outlook of top news around the world and why it matters.
        I want to receive special offers and promotions from Newsweek
By clicking on SIGN ME UP, you agree to Newsweek's  & . You may unsubscribe at any time.
The Facts
Zelensky has been a regular target of misleading video footage shared on social media. A heavily edited video of _Lord of the Rings_ actor Elijah Wood went viral earlier this month  a false narrative that has followed the leader throughout the conflict.
Like others before it, the video of the anti-Zelensky billboard is not real. It's an edit of a video posted two years ago, viewed eight million times, on YouTube showing someone walking around Shibuya, among the busiest and most popular neighborhoods in Tokyo.
! **Exclusively Available to Subscribers** 
The clip used on  appears around 21:20 into the video, shared below.
The billboard shows a few images of Japanese models, not the anti-Zelensky messaging as the edited clip on Twitter suggests.
It's not clear whether regulations and restrictions in Japan would have made the display of such an ad illegal were it shown in Tokyo.
...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Newsweek is a well-established news magazine that provides coverage on a wide array of topics, including politics and international news. While it generally adheres to journalistic standards, its reputation has suffered in recent years due to sensationalist headlines and occasional inaccuracies. However, it occasionally provides comprehensive coverage of fact-checking and disinformation issues, which supports a decent quality score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence directly confirms that the video showing the billboard is altered and that the original footage predates the current geopolitical context. It specifically states that the edited video does not depict the alleged messaging and provides context about the manipulation, thus thoroughly addressing the authenticity of the claim.

metatags.og:title: Tokyo video doctored to add anti-Zelensky billboard
metatags.og:description: A video circulating online appears to show a prominent digital billboard in Japan saying, "Stop war" and "Stop Zelenskyy." But the clip has been doctored; the sign featured people -- not the anti-Ukraine message -- in otherwise matching footage posted to YouTube in 2020, prior to Russia's invasion.

website_content.content:
**Copyright © AFP 2017-2024.** Any commercial use of this content requires a subscription. Click  to find out more.
A video circulating online appears to show a prominent digital billboard in Japan saying, "Stop war" and "Stop Zelenskyy." But the clip has been doctored; the sign featured people -- not the anti-Ukraine message -- in otherwise matching footage posted to YouTube in 2020, prior to Russia's invasion.
"Billboard that says 'Stop Zelensky, Stop War' in Japan," says a  from The Post Millennial, a conservative Canadian website that has previously spread .
Screenshot from Twitter, which is being rebranded as "X," taken August 1, 2023
 posts  the  video  across , which is rebranding as "X," and other  such as ,  and .
Screenshot from Twitter, which is being rebranded as "X," taken August 1, 2023
Screenshot from Twitter, which is being rebranded as "X," taken August 1, 2023
The clip also spread in ,  and .
But  (archived ) from nearly three years ago shows the same digital billboard making no mention of the country's war with Russia or its leader, President Volodymyr Zelensky.
AFP found the original video, titled "Night Walk in Tokyo Shibuya," by conducting a  using . It was posted to YouTube on October...[Content truncated]

The organization has a strong reputation for accuracy and impartial reporting, establishing itself as a trusted resource for combating misinformation and fake news.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence categorically states that the video has been doctored and identifies the original video from 2020, reinforcing the fact that it does not show the message claimed. It offers clarity on the nature of the manipulation, making it highly relevant to the question.

ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Video shows digital billboard in Japan with

website_content.content:
The claim: Video shows digital billboard in Japan with anti-Zelenskyy message
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A July 30 post (, ) on X, formerly Twitter, shows video of a crowd crossing a city street at night.
"'Stop Zelensky, Stop War!' In Japan," reads the video's caption, which is describing a message that seems to appear on a digital billboard.
The video was retweeted more than 9,000 times in four days. It was shared on Facebook more than 50 times, according to CrowdTangle, a social media analytics tool.
**Follow us on Facebook!**
Our rating: Altered
-------------------
The video was altered to include the anti-Zelenskyy billboard. The original video shows a different advertisement in its place, and it was posted online more than a year before Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
Video edited to include anti-Zelenskyy display
----------------------------------------------
The clip in the post was taken from a  uploaded to YouTube on Oct. 18, 2020, by a verified account called "Virtual Japan," which posts  in Japan.
It shows the same buildings, vehicles and people as the clip in the post, but the digital billboard in question does not show a message critical of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Instead, it shows white Japanese writing on a pink background followed by images of people.
An image of the intersection in Shibuya City, Tokyo, taken in October 202...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: USA Today is a widely read U.S. newspaper known for its straightforward reporting. While it offers solid coverage of national events and trends, it sometimes lacks depth in analysis. It has a decent fact-checking record but has faced criticism for focusing more on entertainment and lifestyle content, impacting its overall credibility.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence thoroughly explains that the video was altered to insert the anti-Zelenskyy billboard and details that the original video displayed an entirely different advertisement. It confirms the manipulation with a specific timeline and context, making it very relevant to the inquiry.

ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Video is recent and shows a billboard saying

website_content.content:
A video which shows a digital billboard on a building saying "Stop Zelenskyy, Stop War" is going viral on the internet with users claiming that it was recently put up in 's Shibuya district.
**What have users said?:** Those sharing the video have uploaded it with a caption, "Japan is starting to wake up. An advertising banner appeared on a building in Tokyo, the Shibuya district: 'Stop war. Stop, Zelenskyy'."
!
An archive of the post can be seen .
(Source: X/Screenshot)
A Canadian magazine_, ,_ also shared the video on their official X (formerly known as Twitter) handle. Archives of more similar posts can be viewed , , , and .
**Are these claims true?:** No, the video has been altered to add texts against Ukrainian President . The original video, which dates back to October 2020, featured different people on the billboard.
**How did we find that out?:** Taking Shibuya district as reference, we performed a keyword search on YouTube and came across a video on a verified channel called ''.
*   The video was titled, "4K HDR Night Walk in Tokyo Shibuya (東京散歩)."
*   It was uploaded on 19 October 2020.
*   The longer version also shows people wearing masks, which indicated a possibility of the video being recorded during the pandemic.
...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Quint is an Indian digital news platform that aims to provide a new perspective on news stories. While it does offer substantial journalism, its editorial independence is sometimes questioned. The quality of reporting can vary, which justifies a moderate score reflecting concerns about reliability.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses the viral claim and confirms that the video is altered to present a false narrative about a new billboard message. It cites the existence of an original video and further contextualizes the background, making it relevant but slightly less detailed than others.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]...*   
!
AR
Trending now
*   
*   
!
A Video of the Tokyo Billboard 'Stop War, Stop Zelenskyy' Is Manipulated
============================================================================
Wesam Abo Marq]
!
6th August 2023
!
!
!
The Japanese anti-Zelenskyy sign was manipulated (Twitter)
Emerging story
--------------
Social media users, mainly pro-Russia, circulated a video purporting to feature a banner on a building in Japan with the message: "Stop Zelenskyy! Stop the war!"
!
Misleading
The Claim
---------
A video shows a banner displayed on a building in Japan that reads: "Stop Zelenskyy! Stop the war!"
News posted on
--------------
Spriter]Towhee]Luis]Leandro]Keithb]
Misbar’s Analysis
-----------------
 investigated the widely circulated video and found the claim to be fake.
The video is digitally altered to show the anti-Zelensky billboard.
The Video Showing a Japanese Anti-Zelenskyy Sign Was Manipulated
----------------------------------------------------------------
The original video does not feature the  billboard. The original video dates back to October 19, 2020. The footage shows a person walking around the bustling Shibuya neighborhood in Tokyo, , and videotaping the scene.
!
_**Photo Description:** A screenshot of the original video from YouTube._
's team compared the viral video with the longer original version and discovered that the viral video appears approximately 21:25 into the original video.
!
_**Photo Description:** A screenshot of the original video and the circulating video._
According to the 2022 guidelines set by the Japanese Consumer Affairs Agency, it is not clear whether such a billboard, if real, would be considered prohibited since it does not promote any product or have any affiliation with a Japanese political party or organization.
Furthermore, no reliable media outlets reported the video showing the anti-Zelenskyy message.
Shibuya AI Vision
-----------------
The advertisement banner seen in the video is known as Shibuya Ai Vision. Reports indicate that it is a large vertical screen used to convey messages related to love, birthdays, and special occasions to people globally.
The screen is located near other commercial centers, such as Shibuya Modi and Shibuya 109, with their main entrance at Shibuya crossing, a famous and bustling scramble crossing in Tokyo. Moreover, Shibuya boasts two of the busiest railway stations in the world, namely Shibuya and Shinjuku stations.
!
_**Photo Description...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Misbar is a fact-checking platform that analyzes claims circulating online. While it provides valuable insights, it tends to focus on social media narratives, potentially leading to less comprehensive coverage of broader issues. However, its intent to clarify misinformation boosts its credibility.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence identifies the claim as fake and confirms the video was manipulated. It also establishes that the original footage does not contain the alleged billboard, reinforcing its relevance to discerning the truth behind the claim.

website_content.content:
**Update 20.10.2023:** A video showing the same inscription on a New York building was added to the material. “Myth Detector” cannot rule out that the inscription was projected to the building for a certain period of time, although the verdict of the material remains unchanged because no banner was placed on the building.
On October 18, Facebook users supporting the pro-Kremlin “Conservative Movement” ( , ) published a photo of an English-language banner with the following inscription: “Israel Bombs Hospitals; Biden Pays For It.” According to the description, the banner is placed in New York.
An identical photo was shared by Russian-language Facebook users (, , ) and the online publication .
]]
**The photo disseminated on social media is likely to be altered and it was not placed in Manhattan, New York, which is confirmed by the following signs:**
1.  **No similar banner can be found on the photo and video materials taken on October 18, 2023;**
2.  **The building on which the billboard was supposed to be placed was built in 2019, and no advertising or other types of billboards have been placed on it since that time.**
The photo circulating social networks showing a billboard in New York was taken at night. The photo shows a yellow taxi and several buildings, including...[Content truncated]

It has been effective in exposing fake news narratives, particularly those affecting its region, which supports its credibility.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses a different topic entirely and does not address the claim about the billboard in Japan. It is unrelated to the authenticity of the video in question.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... has done. And by the way, Ukraine is a pure client state of the United States State Department — again, that’s fine. We are not mad about that, go ahead and run Ukraine if you want, if you think you can do a better job than Ukrainians. Just don’t tell us it’s a democracy.”
To some extent, whether Ukraine is a democracy is a matter of opinion, so we will not offer a Pinocchio rating. But Carlson — who has  for Hungarian President Viktor Orbán and his crackdown on civil liberties — is stacking the deck against Ukraine. It is a fledgling democracy, with significant growing pains, largely the result of Russian pressure and interference in its affairs. It is certainly not “a tyranny.”
### The Facts
Ukraine has many aspects of a democracy. The president, who is head of state and commander in chief, is chosen by a popular election. The legislature has a mix of single-seat and proportional representation. The prime minister is chosen through a legislative majority and is head of government. The  is appointed by the president upon  by the Supreme Council of Justice.
“In April 2019 Volodymyr Zelensky was elected president in an election considered free and fair by international and domestic observers,” the State Department said in . “In July 2019 the country held early parliamentary elections that observers also considered free and fair.”
But what’s on paper is not necessarily the same as what happens in practice. Ukraine’s constitution, for instance, guarantees the right to peaceful assembly, but there is no law that specifically provides for freedom of assembly.
The country has struggled to build up a lasting democratic infrastructure as it has veered between leaders who lean toward Russia or toward the West. Corruption remains a serious problem that government officials have only halfheartedly addressed.
Zelensky has been engaged in a bitter political feud with the man he defeated in a landslide 2019 election, Petro Poroshenko. Prosecutors have sought to arrest Poroshenko on charges of treason and supporting terrorism, but a court in January  he could await trial while released on his own recognizance. Poroshenko had been accused of facilitating coal purchases for government enterprises from mines under the control of Moscow-backed insurgents in eastern Ukraine, helping finance the militants. He  the charges are politically motivated.
Freedom House, a nonpartisan think tank that ranks democracies, has  Ukraine “a transitional or hybrid regime” in one recent report and “partly free” in a .
Hungary, Carlson’s fave, is  as...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Washington Post is a renowned American newspaper known for its rigorous journalistic standards and investigative journalism. It has a strong track record of accuracy and reliability, particularly in political reporting. Its commitment to defending facts contributes to a high credibility score, though it is sometimes perceived as having a political bias.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence addresses a separate political discussion unrelated to the claim about the billboard. It adds no value to understanding the authenticity of the video showing the alleged advertisement.
